repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
It'll only need the GIL on failure (which it can get) and "power of" type maths is the soft of thing that people are likely already doing in nogil blocks

Fixes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/5274

This is the last of the fixes for things that I broke in 3.0.0b1 I believe

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
        # it's useful to know if this node is coerced to
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -6414,6 +6414,9 @@ def analyse_declarations(self, env):
         self.lhs.analyse_target_declaration(env)
 
     def analyse_types(self, env):
+        # it's useful to know in this node is coerced to

comment_data.body:
Using `getattr()` in this way always has a code smell. It suggests that we are relying on or introducing special cases that are not well defined. In the call to `binop_node()`, you pass `node.nogil` unconditionally, whereas here, you are not asserting that the attribute exists.

I can see that some `ExprNode`s already have such an attribute. It feels like a slightly clearer name might have been better (Is this node used inside of a nogil section, or does it start one? *Can* it be executed without the GIL or *must* it run without it?), but that's what we have now. If we need to extend what we have, then we should try to stick to the semantics or make them clearer. Maybe `nogil` is a general attribute of an expression node? And maybe we can document it right in `ExprNode` then? Maybe that even allows us to add a general nogil check at that level that subclasses only need to override at need? (The latter might not be for 3.0 any more…)

I think:

Coerce can be at a number of different times in the pipeline. `env.nogil` is only reliable in some transforms. ~`node.nogil` is a general attribute of an expression node, but is set fairly late on pipeline so isn't always available.~ is only set on some types of node. So I was trying to work around that mess.

With that said, I think I have a better way to do it in this case (it can just be deferred until code generation time, when it's definitely known) since we don't make any decisions based on it except writing 0 or 1

I think the best long-term solution is to add `nogil` as a general attribute of a (Expr?)Node.  Or possibly just try to get it from `code` at code-generation time in a few more places.  For now I've added something that I think is slightly less less bad than I had before (It at least has the advantage that all the hackyness is concentrated in one place, which makes it easier to reason about)

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -208,6 +208,53 @@ def pythagoras_with_typedef(double a, double b):
     return result
 
 
+@cython.cpow(False)
+def power_coercion_in_nogil_1(double a, double b):
+    """
+    >>> power_coercion_in_nogil_1(2., 2.)
+    4.0
+    >>> power_coercion_in_nogil_1(-1., 0.5)
+    Traceback (most recent call last):
+    ...
+    TypeError: Cannot convert 'complex' with non-zero imaginary component to 'double' (this most likely comes from the '**' operator; use 'cython.cpow(True)' to return 'nan' instead of a complex number).
+    """
+    cdef double c
+    with nogil:
+        c = a**b
+    return c
+

@@ -2823,7 +2823,7 @@ def side_effect_free_reference(node, setting=False):
                                      operator = node.operator,
                                      operand1 = dup,
                                      operand2 = rhs,
-                                     inplace=True)
+                                     inplace = True)

@@ -14131,23 +14131,35 @@ def analyse_types(self, env):
 
 
 def coerce_from_soft_complex(arg, dst_type, env):
+    from .UtilNodes import HasGilNode
     cfunc_type = PyrexTypes.CFuncType(
         PyrexTypes.c_double_type,
-        [ PyrexTypes.CFuncTypeArg("value", PyrexTypes.soft_complex_type, None) ],
+        [ PyrexTypes.CFuncTypeArg("value", PyrexTypes.soft_complex_type, None),
+          PyrexTypes.CFuncTypeArg("have_gil", PyrexTypes.c_bint_type, None) ],
         exception_value = "-1",
-        exception_check = True
+        exception_check = True,

comment_data.body:
Let's change lines to PEP-8 while we're touching them anyway.
```suggestion
        exception_value="-1",
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -14131,23 +14131,35 @@ def analyse_types(self, env):
 
 
 def coerce_from_soft_complex(arg, dst_type, env):
+    from .UtilNodes import HasGilNode
     cfunc_type = PyrexTypes.CFuncType(
         PyrexTypes.c_double_type,
-        [ PyrexTypes.CFuncTypeArg("value", PyrexTypes.soft_complex_type, None) ],
+        [ PyrexTypes.CFuncTypeArg("value", PyrexTypes.soft_complex_type, None),
+          PyrexTypes.CFuncTypeArg("have_gil", PyrexTypes.c_bint_type, None) ],
         exception_value = "-1",

comment_data.body:
:-O That's … ugly.

It looks like `SimpleCallNode` doesn't even need the `nogil` attribute. Its `generate_result_code()` method can also just figure it out from `code.funcstate.gil_owned`, why not? I quickly checked its subclasses and they don't seem to make use of it. Let's get rid of the attribute all together.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -14131,23 +14131,35 @@ def analyse_types(self, env):
 
 
 def coerce_from_soft_complex(arg, dst_type, env):
+    from .UtilNodes import HasGilNode
     cfunc_type = PyrexTypes.CFuncType(
         PyrexTypes.c_double_type,
-        [ PyrexTypes.CFuncTypeArg("value", PyrexTypes.soft_complex_type, None) ],
+        [ PyrexTypes.CFuncTypeArg("value", PyrexTypes.soft_complex_type, None),
+          PyrexTypes.CFuncTypeArg("have_gil", PyrexTypes.c_bint_type, None) ],
         exception_value = "-1",
-        exception_check = True
+        exception_check = True,
+        nogil=True  # We can acquire the GIL internally on failure
     )
     call = PythonCapiCallNode(
         arg.pos,
         "__Pyx_SoftComplexToDouble",
         cfunc_type,
         utility_code = UtilityCode.load_cached("SoftComplexToDouble", "Complex.c"),
-        args = [arg]
+        args = [arg, HasGilNode(arg.pos)],
     )
-    call = call.analyse_types(env)
-    if call.type != dst_type:
-        call = call.coerce_to(dst_type, env)
-    return call
+    # Because this function can be called from outside analyse_types
+    # (e.g. from ExpandInPlaceOperatorsTransform)
+    # we can't rely on env.nogil being right. Therefore monkey-patch
+    # generate_result_code to work out the gil state then
+    old_generate_result_code = call.generate_result_code
+    def new_generate_result_code(code):
+        call.nogil = not code.funcstate.gil_owned
+        return old_generate_result_code(code)
+    call.generate_result_code = new_generate_result_code
+    analysed_call = call.analyse_types(env)
+    if analysed_call.type != dst_type:
+        analysed_call = analysed_call.coerce_to(dst_type, env)
+    return analysed_call

commit.message:
Allow soft-complex->double coercion to run without gil

It'll only need the GIL on failure (which it can get)
and "power of" type maths is the soft of thing that people are
likely already doing in nogil blocks
Try to avoid getattr nogil mess

Apply suggestions from code review

Co-authored-by: scoder <stefan_ml@behnel.de>

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3str`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Allow soft-complex->double coercion to run without gil
